Original: Absolute perfection in no direction, relative perfection in all other manifestations
Corrected: in all manifestations.
Review: in all <mark><s>other</s></mark> manifestations.
Decision: The word other removed. This phase of perfection exists in only one manifestation—relative perfection.

Original: Deified reality embraces all of infinite Deity potentials
Corrected: all infinite Deity potentials
Review: all <mark><s>of</s></mark> infinite Deity potentials
Decision: The 1955 construction is awkward because all of is used to modify potentials without the latter being qualified by a limiting adjective.

Original: The relatively quiet zone between the space levels
Corrected: relatively quiet zones
Review: relatively quiet zone<mark>s</mark>
Decision: The plural agrees with the verb are.

Original: the vast universes of outer space in the realms
Corrected: of outer space, in the realms
Review: of outer space<mark>,</mark> in the realms
Decision: The comma is required to set off the parenthetical phrase.

Original: Tertiary circuit supervisor No. 572,842
Corrected: Tertiary circuit supervisor number 572,842
Review: Tertiary Circuit Supervisor <mark><s>No.</s> number</mark> 572,842
Decision: The spelled-out version is appropriate in this context.

Original: The Significance of Origins are the living
Corrected: The Significances of Origins are
Review: The Significance<mark>s</mark> of Origins are
Decision: The plural is required to agree with the verb are.

Original: the Significance of Origins teach
Corrected: the Significances of Origins teach
Review: the Significance<mark>s</mark> of Origins teach
Decision: The plural is required to agree with the verb are.

Original: the Seven Supreme Power Directors and the Seven Central Supervisors
Corrected: the Seven Center Supervisors
Review: the Seven <mark><s>Central</s> Center</mark> Supervisors
Decision: There is no other reference to Seven Central Supervisors, but there are multiple references to Seven Center Supervisors who function closely with the Supreme Power Directors.

Original: beings enroute elsewhere who pause
Corrected: beings en route elsewhere who pause
Review: beings <mark><s>enroute</s> en route</mark> elsewhere who pause
Decision: Enroute is incorrect French and is not the form that has been adopted into English.

Original: subsequently add any thing new or supplemental
Corrected: subsequently add anything new
Review: subsequently add <mark><s>any thing</s> anything</mark> new
Decision: The closed word is the correct choice in this case.

Original: Andovontia is the name of the secondary Universe Circuit Supervisor
Corrected: tertiary Universe Circuit Supervisor
Review: secondary tertiary Universe Circuit Supervisor
Decision: Only the tertiary Circuit Supervisor is stationed within the local universe.

Original: Within the domain of this Paradise Son of God the Supreme Power Centers
Corrected: Paradise Son of God, the Supreme Power Centers
Review: Paradise Son of God<mark>,</mark> the Supreme Power Centers
Decision: The comma indicates the end of the prepositional phrase.

Original: having become sixty thousand times as dense as your sun
Corrected: having become forty thousand times as dense
Review: having become <mark><s>sixty</s> forty</mark> thousand times as dense
Decision: Textual consistency and current scientific estimates of our sun’s density both support forty thousand.

Original: ten octaves up are the X rays, followed by the Y rays of radium
Corrected: the gamma rays of radium
Review: the <mark><s>Y rays</s> gamma rays</mark> of radium
Decision: Y rays written out as gamma rays.

Original: an electron weighs a little less than 1/2,000th of the smallest atom
Corrected: an electron weighs a little more than
Review: an electron weighs a little <mark><s>less</s> more</mark> than
Decision: More is consistent with 42:6.8, where the author states that a proton is eighteen hundred times as heavy as an electron, and is also in general agreement with current scientific opinion which places the ratio at about 1:1836.

Original: The positive proton... weighs from two to three thousand times more
Corrected: weighs almost two thousand times more
Review: weighs <mark><s>from two to three</s> almost two</mark> thousand times more
Decision: The calculation of the relative masses of the electron and the hydrogen atom was undergoing a rapid evolution just prior to the writing of The Urantia Book, the ratio being 1:1700 in 1897; 1:2000 in 1904; and 1:1845 by 1922. This last ratio is also the one quoted in the 1934 Webster’s Dictionary.

Original: reality from the absoluteness of Paradise monota
Corrected: relative cosmic reality, from the
Review: relative cosmic reality<mark>,</mark> from the
Decision: The comma correctly separates the following parenthetical phrase.

Original: established almost four thousand years ago,
Corrected: established almost forty thousand years ago
Review: established almost <mark><s>four</s> forty</mark> thousand years ago
Decision: The announcement was made shortly after the default of Adam and Eve which occurred about 37,800 years ago.

Original: you are rekeyed each time
Corrected: you are re-keyed each time
Review: you are <mark><s>rekeyed</s> re-keyed</mark> each time
Decision: The only other occurrence of re-keyed is in hyphenated form at 48:2.21.

Original: universe headquarters worlds, may be found
Corrected: universe headquarters worlds may be found
Review: universe headquarters worlds<mark><s>,</s></mark> may be found
Decision: Although technically acceptable, the comma makes the sentence more difficult to read.

Original: Some time they hope to be granted virtually complete
Corrected: Sometime they hope to be granted
Review: <mark><s>Some time</s> Sometime</mark> they hope to be granted
Decision: The closed form is correct as the reference is to an indefinite point in time rather than to an indefinite period of time.

Original: training spheres of the universe, the superuniverse, and of Havona
Corrected: spheres of the universe, the superuniverse, and Havona
Review: spheres of the universe, the superuniverse, and <mark><s>of</s></mark> Havona
Decision: Parallel structure established by removing the word of.

Original: In your world, even in the face of
Corrected: On your world, even in the face of
Review: <mark><s>In</s> On</mark> your world, even in the face of
Decision: This does not appear to be a valid use of in.

Original: Of the 681,227 Material Sons lost in Satania
Corrected: Of the 681,217 Material Sons lost in Satania
Review: Of the <mark><s>681,227</s> 681,217</mark> Material Sons lost in Satania
Decision: The correction from 681,227 to 681,217 was made because of the original’s conflict with 51:1.5.

Original: the ministering-spirit quartette
Corrected: the ministering-spirit quartet
Review: the ministering-spirit <mark><s>quartette</s> quartet</mark>
Decision: Quartette and quartet each occur once in The Urantia Book. There is no differentiation in meaning between the two spellings, so the text has been standardized to quartet to facilitate electronic searching.

Original: The ministering-spirit quartettes consist of
Corrected: The ministering-spirit quartets consist of
Review: The ministering-spirit <mark><s>quartettes</s> quartets</mark> consist of
Decision: Quartettes and quartets each occur once in The Urantia Book. There is no differentiation in meaning between the two spellings, so the text has been standardized to quartets to facilitate electronic searching.

Original: On the worlds the Trinity Teacher Sons
Corrected: On these worlds the Trinity Teacher Sons
Review: On <mark><s>the</s> these</mark> worlds the Trinity Teacher Sons
Decision: The demonstrative adjective these distinguishes which worlds are being discussed.

Original: on the other hand the new orders of beings
Corrected: on the other hand, the new orders of beings
Review: on the other hand<mark>,</mark> the new orders of beings
Decision: The structure of the sentence calls for a comma.

Original: 900,000,000,000 years ago the Uversa archives testify
Corrected: 900,000,000,000 years ago, the Uversa archives testify
Review: 900,000,000,000 years ago, the Uversa archives testify
Decision: The comma properly encloses the descriptive phrase.

Original: life has a marine origin the ideal conditions
Corrected: life has a marine origin, the ideal conditions
Review: life has a marine origin<mark>,</mark> the ideal conditions
Decision: The comma is required.

Original: about one two-billionths
Corrected: about one two-billionth
Review: about one <mark><s>two-billionths</s> two-billionth</mark>
Decision: The singular is correct.

Original: Ameba are typical survivors
Corrected: Amebas are typical survivors
Review: <mark><s>Ameba</s> Amebas</mark> are typical survivors
Decision: The plural is required here to agree with are.

Original: a veritable tropic Paradise
Corrected: a veritable tropic paradise
Review: a veritable tropic <mark><s>Paradise</s></mark> paradise
Decision: Paradise should be lower case.

Original: the muscles, clams, oysters, and scallops
Corrected: the mussels, clams, oysters, and scallops
Review: the <mark><s>muscles</s></mark> mussels, clams, oysters, and scallops
Decision: Muscles is now so uncommon for this meaning that the modern form has been adopted.

Original: marine-life evolution, the age of fishes
Corrected: marine-life evolution, the age of fishes
Review: marine-life evolution, the the age of fishes
Decision: The article the removed from italics.

Original: 85,000,000 years ago Bering Strait closed
Corrected: 85,000,000 years ago the Bering Strait
Review: 85,000,000 years ago the Bering Strait
Decision: The usage was correct when The Urantia Book was written but is now so unfamiliar that the insertion is justified.

Original: But some time previously there had appeared
Corrected: But sometime previously there had appeared
Review: But <mark><s>some time</s> sometime</mark> previously there had appeared
Decision: The closed form is correct as the reference is to an indefinite point in time rather than to an indefinite period of time.

Original: the Panama Isthmus went up
Corrected: the Panama isthmus went up
Review: the Panama <mark><s>Isthmus</s> isthmus</mark> went up
Decision: Capitalization is used only for the formal name of a geographical feature.

Original: three times Bering Strait land bridge
Corrected: three times the Bering Strait land bridge
Review: three times <mark>the</mark> Bering Strait land bridge
Decision: The usage was correct when The Urantia Book was written but is now so unfamiliar that the insertion is justified.

Original: Bering Strait land bridge was up
Corrected: The Bering Strait land bridge was up
Review: <mark>The</mark> Bering Strait land bridge was up
Decision: The usage was correct when The Urantia Book was written but is now so unfamiliar that the insertion is justified.

Original: Weasels, martins, otters, and raccoons
Corrected: Weasels, martens, otters, and raccoons thrived
Review: Weasels, <mark><s>martins</s> martens</mark>, otters, and raccoons thrived
Decision: Martins is now so uncommon for this meaning that the modern form has been adopted.

Original: most of the State of Iowa
Corrected: most of the state of Iowa
Review: most of the <mark><s>State</s> state</mark> of Iowa
Decision: Capitalization removed from State.

Original: beginning of the Holocene or postglacial period
Corrected: the beginning of the Holocene or postglacial period
Review: the beginning of the Holocene Holocene or postglacial period
Decision: All other geologic periods are italicized.

Original: the flint flakers and stonemasons
Corrected: the flint flakers and stone masons
Review: the flint flakers and <mark><s>stonemasons</s> stone masons</mark>
Decision: The spelling has been standardized to the open form.

Original: The dispensation of the Prince has passed, the age of Adam
Corrected: The dispensation of the Prince has passed; the age of Adam
Review: The dispensation of the Prince has passed<mark><s>,</s>;</mark> the age of Adam
Decision: The initial clause is a complete sentence; a semicolon is the correct way of linking the two parts of the larger sentence.

Original: In the days of the first Eden Adam had indeed
Corrected: In the days of the first Eden, Adam had
Review: In the days of the first Eden<mark>,</mark> Adam had
Decision: The comma appropriately separates the initial adverbial phrase.

Original: a descendant of Nod, was indorsed
Corrected: a descendant of Nod, was endorsed.
Review: a descendant of Nod, was <mark><s>indorsed</s> endorsed</mark>.
Decision: Indorsed is obsolete, the modern form endorsed is justified.

Original: as to the purpose of building the tower.
Corrected: the purpose of building the tower:
Review: the purpose of building the tower<mark><s>.</s>:</mark>
Decision: This sentence clearly introduces a list, so the colon is appropriate.

Original: all sorts of sick peoples
Corrected: all sorts of sick people
Review: all sorts of sick <mark><s>peoples</s> people</mark>
Decision: Peoples indicate not multiple individuals but multiple large groups of people.

Original: a civilization in anyway comparable
Corrected: a civilization in any way comparable
Review: a civilization in <mark><s>anyway</s> any way</mark> comparable
Decision: The two-word form any way is the appropriate choice when serving as an adverb.

Original: commerical civilization of the world
Corrected: commercial civilization of the world
Review: <mark><s>commerical</s> commercial</mark> civilization of the world
Decision: Simply a spelling error in typesetting.

Original: land passage to the west, over the Bering isthmus
Corrected: land passage to the West, over the Bering isthmus
Review: land passage to the <mark><s>west</s> West</mark>, over the Bering isthmus
Decision: West is referring to the Western Hemisphere, thus indicating a place rather than a direction of travel.

Original: disruption of Graeco-Roman civilization
Corrected: disruption of Greco-Roman civilization
Review: disruption of <mark><s>Graeco</s> Greco</mark>-Roman civilization
Decision: The more modern form was decided upon.

Original: level of the Atlantic Ocean Presently the
Corrected: level of the Atlantic Ocean. Presently the
Review: level of the Atlantic Ocean<mark>.</mark> Presently the
Decision: This period, at the end of the last line on the page in the original format, was missing in the first printing.

Original: Central Europe was for sometime controlled by
Corrected: Central Europe was for some time controlled by
Review: Central Europe was for <mark><s>sometime</s> some time</mark> controlled by
Decision: The two-word form is correct as the reference is to an indefinite period of time.

Original: there persisted for sometime a superior civilization
Corrected: there persisted for some time a superior civilization
Review: there persisted for <mark><s>sometime</s> some time</mark> a superior civilization
Decision: The two-word form is correct as the reference is to an indefinite period of time.

Original: a life-long partnership of self-effacement
Corrected: a lifelong partnership of self-effacement
Review: a <mark><s>life-long</s> lifelong</mark> partnership of self-effacement
Decision: Standardization was decided here.

Original: enhancement of parental instinct. Each generation
Corrected: enhancement of parental instinct—each generation
Review: enhancement of parental instinct<mark><s>. Each</s>—each</mark> generation
Decision: The correction makes this section consistent with the other three items of this series.

Original: The children of Badanon developed
Corrected: The children of Badonan developed
Review: The children of <mark><s>Badanon</s> Badonan</mark> developed
Decision: Badonan is the correct spelling.

Original: make sure that some one would provide
Corrected: make sure that someone would provide
Review: make sure that <mark><s>some one</s> someone</mark> would provide
Decision: The compound form is used when the group of which the "one" is a member is not specified.

Original: grew up as a defense against evil eye
Corrected: grew up as a defense against the evil eye
Review: grew up as a defense against <mark>the</mark> evil eye
Decision: The phrase evil eye without an article seems extremely stilted.

Original: good luck, evil eye, and astrology
Corrected: good luck, the evil eye, and astrology
Review: good luck, <mark>the</mark> evil eye, and astrology
Decision: The phrase evil eye without an article seems extremely stilted.

Original: the custom to forego many forms
Corrected: the custom to forgo many forms
Review: the custom to <mark><s>forego</s> forgo</mark> many forms
Decision: The corrected spelling of forgo is etymologically preferable.

Original: 5,740,352 sacks of coin
Corrected: 5,740,352 sacks of corn
Review: 5,740,352 sacks of <mark><s>coin</s> corn</mark>
Decision: The list of gifts to the Gods is excerpted from the Harris Papyrus I, which predates the earliest significant presence of coins in Egypt by 650-750 years.

Original: dedication to life-long virginity
Corrected: dedication to lifelong virginity
Review: dedication to <mark><s>life-long</s> lifelong</mark> virginity
Decision: Standardization was decided here.

Original: the Shawnee Teuskwatawa,
Corrected: the Shawnee Tenskwatawa,
Review: the Shawnee <mark><s>Teuskwatawa</s> Tenskwatawa</mark>,
Decision: Tenskwatawa is the standard transliteration for the Shawnee prophet’s name.

Original: the eclipse of the sun in 1808
Corrected: the eclipse of the sun in 1806
Review: the eclipse of the sun in <mark><s>1808</s> 1806</mark>
Decision: The date in the text has been corrected because the incident actually occurred in 1806.

Original: religions of ancient times were Judaism and Hinduism, and each
Corrected: religions of ancient times were Hinduism and Judaism, and each
Review: religions of ancient times were <mark><s>Judaism and Hinduism</s> Hinduism and Judaism</mark>, and each
Decision: The correction in word order is consistent with the subsequent phraseology, “...each respectively...in Orient and Occident.” At some point it appears a transcription error was made and this is the simplest way to restore the intended meaning.

Original: Level values—loyalties
Corrected: Level of values—loyalties
Review: Level <mark>of</mark> values—loyalties
Decision: Level values has no discernible meaning; Level of values is meaningful, consistent with the context, and is consistent with the other three items in this series.

Original: for Abraham to forego
Corrected: for Abraham to forgo
Review: for Abraham to <mark><s>forego</s> forgo</mark>
Decision: The corrected spelling of forgo is etymologically preferable.

Original: such as Agni, Indra, Soma
Corrected: such as Agni, Indra, and Soma
Review: such as Agni, Indra, <mark>and</mark> Soma
Decision: The conjunction and between the last two elements of a series gives the reader an indication that the series is complete.

Original: and in this country, far distant from Salem
Corrected: and in this country, far-distant
Review: and in this country, <mark><s>far distant</s> far-distant</mark>
Decision: The decision to standardize usage is in agreement with Webster’s of 1934.

Original: He taught that “man’s eternal destiny was everlasting union with Tao
Corrected: He taught that man’s eternal destiny was “everlasting union
Review: He taught that <mark><s>“</s></mark>man’s eternal destiny was <mark>“</mark>everlasting union
Decision: The relocation of the opening quotation mark resolves the difficulty.

Original: Such teaching gained the ascendency
Corrected: Such teaching gained the ascendancy
Review: Such teaching gained the <mark><s>ascendency</s> ascendancy</mark>
Decision: Ascendancy is first choice of Webster’s and is definitely preferred above ascendency.

Original: in the Arabian desert
Corrected: in the Arabian Desert
Review: in the Arabian <mark><s>desert</s> Desert</mark>
Decision: The correct form is Arabian Desert.

Original: to the Arabian desert
Corrected: to the Arabian Desert
Review: to the Arabian <mark><s>desert</s> Desert</mark>
Decision: The correct form is Arabian Desert.

Original: But none the less he sought
Corrected: But nonetheless he sought
Review: But <mark><s>none the less</s> nonetheless</mark> he sought
Decision: None the less is used when the meaning is equivalent to no less, and nonetheless is used when the meaning approximates even so.

Original: walk humbly with your God."
Corrected: walk humbly with your God?”
Review: walk humbly with your God<mark><s>.</s>?</mark>”
Decision: This quote is punctuated as found in the Revised Version Bible.

Original: the ascendency of Egypt brought
Corrected: the ascendancy of Egypt brought
Review: the <mark><s>ascendency</s> ascendancy</mark> of Egypt brought
Decision: Ascendancy is first choice of Webster’s and is definitely preferred above ascendency.

Original: more than twoscore self-elevated human deities
Corrected: more than two-score self-elevated human deities
Review: more than <mark><s>twoscore</s> two-score</mark> self-elevated human deities
Decision: The hyphenated form is the consistent usage elsewhere in the text. The decision was made to standardize on that form.

Original: people in the Graeco-Roman world
Corrected: people in the Greco-Roman world
Review: people in the <mark><s>Graeco</s> Greco</mark>-Roman world
Decision: The more modern form was decided upon.

Original: If some one irritates you
Corrected: If someone irritates you
Review: If <mark><s>some one</s> someone</mark> irritates you
Decision: The two-word form is appropriate when referring to some one member of a particular group.

Original: Only in the second sketch you are favored
Corrected: Only, in the second sketch you are favored
Review: Only<mark>,</mark> in the second sketch you are favored
Decision: The comma after Only is required to convey the intended meaning, which approximates “however."

Original: adverse ani malistic tendencies. (missing hyphen at end of line)
Corrected: adverse animalistic tendencies
Review: adverse <mark><s>ani malistic</s> animalistic</mark> tendencies
Decision: The required hyphen at the end of the line was inserted. This issue does not occur in the electronic texts.

Original: cosmic levels of the Supreme mind
Corrected: cosmic levels of the Supreme Mind
Review: cosmic levels of the Supreme <mark><s>mind</s> Mind</mark>
Decision: Chicago Manual of Style steadfastly recommends capitalization for names for Deity. Therefore, when using Supreme Mind as a two-word noun/name, Mind should be capitalized.

Original: consciousness of true reality;
Corrected: consciousness of true reality;
Review: consciousness of true reality;;
Decision: Semicolon italicized.

Original: Science indicates Deity as a fact;
Corrected: Science indicates Deity as a fact;
Review: Science indicates Deity as a fact;;
Decision: Semicolon italicized.

Original: Ethics is the eternal social or racial mirror
Corrected: Ethics is the external social or racial mirror
Review: Ethics is the <mark><s>eternal</s> external</mark> social or racial mirror
Decision: Correcting eternal to external on the basis of an assumed keystroke error makes the sentence clear in meaning and reveals a contrastive point which is completely absent from the original.

Original: corelater of the absolute and the relative
Corrected: correlator of the absolute and the relative
Review: <mark><s>corelator</s> correlator</mark> of the absolute and the relative
Decision: Correlator, the now standard form, is found five times elsewhere in the text.

Original: the eternity co-existence of the Son
Corrected: the eternity coexistence of the Son
Review: the eternity <mark><s>co-existence</s> coexistence</mark> of the Son
Decision: The hyphenated form is not found elsewhere in the text and is not supported.

Original: and the Unrevealed Consummator of
Corrected: and the unrevealed Consummator of
Review: and the <mark><s>Unrevealed</s> unrevealed</mark> Consummator of
Decision: The lowercase version is correct because unrevealed is solely descriptive.

Original: the unknown potential of Supreme mind
Corrected: the unknown potential of Supreme Mind
Review: the unknown potential of Supreme <mark><s>mind</s> Mind</mark>
Decision: Chicago Manual of Style steadfastly recommends capitalization for names for Deity.

Original: Personalized Thought Adjusters are the untrammeled
Corrected: Personalized Thought Adjusters are the untrammeled
Review: Personalized Thought Adjusters are the <mark><s>untrammelled</s> untrammeled</mark>
Decision: Untrammeled is the consistent usage elsewhere in the text and is preferred by Chicago Manual of Style.

Original: compatible with a light-hearted and joyous life
Corrected: compatible with a lighthearted and joyous life
Review: compatible with a <mark><s>light-hearted</s> lighthearted</mark> and joyous life
Decision: All other occurrences in the text follow the compound form, lighthearted.

Original: the ka and the ba;
Corrected: the ka and the ba;
Review: the ka and the ba;;
Decision: The semicolon should be italicized.

Original: Vertical depth embraces the organismal drives
Corrected: Vertical depth embraces the organismal drives
Review: Vertical depth depth embraces the organismal drives
Decision: Vertical and depth should both be italicized as together they form the substantive paralleled by the other items in the context.

Original: the Jerusem corps of twenty-four planetary supervisors designate one
Corrected: the Jerusem corps of twenty-four planetary supervisors designates one
Review: the Jerusem corps of twenty-four planetary supervisors <mark><s>designate</s> designates</mark> one
Decision: The word corps, being a collective noun, requires a singular verb form for correct noun/verb agreement.

Original: while the united midwayers,
Corrected: while the United Midwayers,
Review: while the <mark><s>united midwayers</s> United Midwayers</mark>,
Decision: United Midwayers is the usual form of the term.

Original: Qualified Vicegerents of the Ultimate
Corrected: Qualified Vicegerents of the Ultimate.
Review: Qualified Vicegerents of the Ultimate<mark>.</mark>
Decision: This period was missing in many copies of the 1955 text but it very faintly appears in others, apparently being worn down in the course of the printing.

Original: any violence to the freewillness
Corrected: any violence to the free-willness
Review: any violence to the <mark><s>freewillness</s> free-willness</mark>
Decision: Free-willness is found at four other locations in the text and in all instances it refers to an attribute or characteristic of a being or beings.

Original: the colossal error of Pantheism
Corrected: the colossal error of pantheism
Review: the colossal error of <mark><s>Pantheism</s> pantheism</mark>
Decision: Though religions and even philosophical schools are normally capitalized, pantheism is more of a philosophical concept and is not capitalized.

Original: Jesus has promised some time to return
Corrected: Jesus has promised sometime to return
Review: Jesus has promised <mark><s>some time</s> sometime</mark> to return
Decision: The closed form of sometime is correct.

Original: did not hestitate to clash
Corrected: did not hesitate to clash
Review: did not <mark><s>hestitate</s> hesitate</mark> to clash
Decision: Simple typesetting spelling error.

Original: his fifth birthday anniversay
Corrected: his fifth birthday anniversary
Review: his fifth birthday <mark><s>anniversay</s> anniversary</mark>
Decision: Simple typesetting spelling error.

Original: on pleasure or business to nearby Cana
Corrected: on pleasure or business to near-by Cana
Review: on pleasure or business to <mark><s>nearby</s> near-by</mark> Cana
Decision: All other instances of near-by as an adjective are hyphenated.

Original: to view the “gate beautiful,” the artistic gate
Corrected: to view the “Gate Beautiful,” the artistic gate
Review: to view the “<mark><s>gate beautiful</s> Gate Beautiful</mark>,” the artistic gate
Decision: Gate Beautiful is clearly one name for this gate; therefore capitalization is appropriate.

Original: he could look upon Tannach
Corrected: he could look upon Taanach
Review: he could look upon <mark><s>Tannach</s> Taanach</mark>
Decision: Taanach is the correct spelling and standard transliteration of the name.

Original: superhuman or miraculous peformance
Corrected: superhuman or miraculous performance
Review: superhuman or miraculous <mark><s>peformance</s> performance</mark>
Decision: Simple typesetting spelling error.

Original: and the bond-servant of depression
Corrected: and the bond servant of depression and defeat
Review: and the <mark><s>bond-servant</s> bond servant</mark> of depression and defeat
Decision: The only form found in Webster’s is the open form. Therefore, the decision was made to standardize on that form.

Original: if any one should be so unthinking
Corrected: if anyone should be so unthinking
Review: if <mark><s>any one</s> anyone</mark> should be so unthinking
Decision: Anyone is correct if anybody could be substituted.

Original: functioning of a consciousness sorter and associater
Corrected: functioning of a consciousness sorter and associator
Review: functioning of a consciousness sorter and <mark><s>associater</s> associator</mark>
Decision: The common form, associator, is the consistent usage elsewhere in the text.

Original: religion began at 10:00 o’clock
Corrected: religion began at ten o’clock
Review: religion began at <mark><s>10:00</s> ten</mark> o’clock
Decision: The spelled-out form for time is clearly supported in Chicago Manual of Style.

Original: sessions started at 3:00 o’clock
Corrected: sessions started at three o’clock
Review: sessions started at <mark><s>3:00</s> three</mark> o’clock
Decision: The spelled-out form for time is clearly supported in Chicago Manual of Style.

Original: debates opened at 8:00 o’clock
Corrected: debates opened at eight o’clock
Review: debates opened at <mark><s>8:00</s> eight</mark> o’clock
Decision: The spelled-out form for time is clearly supported in Chicago Manual of Style.

Original: Sychar, Schecham
Corrected: Sychar, Shechem
Review: Sychar, <mark><s>Schecham</s> Shechem</mark>
Decision: Shechem is the standard transliteration of the name.

Original: Caesarea Philippi
Corrected: Caesarea-Philippi
Review: Caesarea<mark>-</mark>Philippi
Decision: Given the almost universal consistency of usage in the text, the hyphenated form must have been the author’s choice.

Original: Caesarea Philippi
Corrected: Caesarea-Philippi
Review: Caesarea<mark>-</mark>Philippi
Decision: Correction to hyphenated form.

Original: took place some time before his baptism
Corrected: took place sometime before his baptism
Review: took place <mark><s>some time</s> sometime</mark> before his baptism
Decision: The closed form sometime is correct as the reference is to an indefinite point in time.

Original: fresh, first-hand reports
Corrected: fresh, firsthand reports
Review: fresh, <mark><s>first-hand</s> firsthand</mark> reports
Decision: Of the five occurrences of firsthand and first-hand, only this one is hyphenated; no differentiation in usage exists.

Original: bridegroom who stands near-by
Corrected: bridegroom who stands near by
Review: bridegroom who stands <mark><s>near-by</s> near by</mark>
Decision: Consistent adverb usage supports this correction to the open form.

Original: Michael No. 611,121
Corrected: Michael number 611,121
Review: Michael <mark><s>No.</s> number</mark> 611,121
Decision: The spelled-out version is appropriate in this context.

Original: this momentous dialog of Jesus’
Corrected: this momentous dialogue of Jesus’
Review: this momentous <mark><s>dialog</s> dialogue</mark> of Jesus’
Decision: Though this is a more modern and American English form, it is the only instance. Multiple instances of dialogue are found.

Original: their first clearcut and positive
Corrected: their first clear-cut and positive
Review: their first <mark><s>clearcut</s> clear-cut</mark> and positive
Decision: This word is found eight additional times; all are hyphenated.

Original: Judas’ parents were Sadducees
Corrected: Judas’s parents were Sadducees
Review: Judas<mark>’s</mark> parents were Sadducees
Decision: The correct form is Judas’s.

Original: He was liberal, bighearted, learned, and tolerant
Corrected: He was liberal, big-hearted, learned, and tolerant
Review: He was liberal, <mark><s>bighearted</s> big-hearted</mark>, learned, and tolerant
Decision: The only other occurrence of this word is hyphenated, so it was decided to standardize on this version.

Original: The Sabbath week ends they usually spent
Corrected: The Sabbath weekends they usually spent
Review: The Sabbath <mark><s>week ends</s> weekends</mark> they usually spent
Decision: The closed form has become the standard usage and has been adopted.

Original: that I thirst not neither come all the way
Corrected: that I thirst not, neither come all the way
Review: that I thirst not<mark>,</mark> neither come all the way
Decision: The comma properly separates the phrases, making this sentence easier to read.

Original: preach at the week-day evening
Corrected: preach at the weekday evening
Review: preach at the <mark><s>week-day</s> weekday</mark> evening
Decision: The closed form has become the standard usage and has been adopted.

Original: the encouragement of evil doing
Corrected: the encouragement of evil-doing
Review: the encouragement of <mark><s>evil doing</s> evil-doing</mark>
Decision: There has been a clear preference for the hyphenated form since the seventeenth century.

Original: He was a half-hearted believer
Corrected: He was a halfhearted believer
Review: He was a <mark><s>half-hearted</s> halfhearted</mark> believer
Decision: The closed form is the consistent usage elsewhere in the text. The decision was made to standardize on that form.

Original: the Master among other things said, in reply
Corrected: the Master, among other things, said in reply
Review: the Master<mark>,</mark> among other things<mark>,</mark> said<mark><s>,</s></mark> in reply
Decision: This required two corrections: a comma was inserted after the Master, and a pre-existing comma that followed said was moved in front.

Original: return to Bethsaida some time on Thursday
Corrected: return to Bethsaida sometime on Thursday
Review: return to Bethsaida <mark><s>some time</s> sometime</mark> on Thursday
Decision: The reference is to an indefinite point in time, therefore sometime is correct.

Original: confined in one of the grottos
Corrected: confined in one of the grottoes
Review: confined in one of the <mark><s>grottos</s> grottoes</mark>
Decision: Though both forms are correct, this word is found elsewhere in the text as grottoes. The text was standardized on that form.

Original: you are short-sighted and material-minded
Corrected: you are shortsighted and material-minded
Review: you are <mark><s>short-sighted</s> shortsighted</mark> and material-minded
Decision: The closed form is the consistent usage elsewhere.

Original: Jairus’ only reply to all this
Corrected: Jairus’s only reply to all this
Review: Jairus<mark>’s</mark> only reply to all this
Decision: The correct form is Jairus’s.

Original: But hearken to me all of you
Corrected: But hearken to me, all of you
Review: But hearken to me<mark>,</mark> all of you
Decision: The comma properly separates the phrases, making the sentence easier to read.

Original: accepted the tax, foregoing the penalty
Corrected: accepted the tax, forgoing the penalty for tardy payment
Review: accepted the tax, <mark><s>foregoing</s> forgoing</mark> the penalty for tardy payment
Decision: The corrected spelling of forgoing is etymologically preferable.

Original: Come out of him you unclean spirit
Corrected: Come out of him, you unclean spirit
Review: Come out of him<mark>,</mark> you unclean spirit
Decision: The comma properly separates the phrases, making this sentence easier to read.

Original: slept very little that night;
Corrected: slept very little that night,
Review: slept very little that night<mark><s>;</s>,</mark>
Decision: The semicolon is too strong a separator. A comma is more appropriate.

Original: there is deliberate evildoing and sinful rebellion
Corrected: there is deliberate evil-doing and sinful rebellion
Review: there is deliberate <mark><s>evildoing</s> evil-doing</mark> and sinful rebellion
Decision: There has been a clear preference for the hyphenated form since the seventeenth century.

Original: they are at once restful and time-saving
Corrected: they are at once restful and timesaving
Review: they are at once restful and <mark><s>time-saving</s> timesaving</mark>
Decision: Though the original is clear, the closed form is the common one and was approved in Webster’s 1934.

Original: He says that any one who has seen him
Corrected: He says that anyone who has seen him
Review: He says that <mark><s>any one</s> anyone</mark> who has seen him
Decision: The closed form is correct.

Original: than this Jesus of Nazareth has already done?
Corrected: than this Jesus of Nazareth has already done.
Review: than this Jesus of Nazareth has already done<mark><s>?</s>.</mark>
Decision: This is an indirect question contained within a declarative sentence, so the period is correct.

Original: toward the beautiful gate
Corrected: toward the Beautiful Gate
Review: toward the <mark><s>beautiful gate</s> Beautiful Gate</mark>
Decision: Beautiful Gate is clearly one name for this gate; therefore capitalization is appropriate.

Original: who commits sin is the bond-servant of sin
Corrected: who commits sin is the bond servant of sin
Review: who commits sin is the <mark><s>bondservant</s> bond servant</mark> of sin
Decision: The only form found in Webster’s is the open form.

Original: the bondservant is not likely
Corrected: the bond servant is not likely
Review: the <mark><s>bondservant</s> bond servant</mark> is not likely
Decision: The only form found in Webster’s is the open form.

Original: during the times of Judas Maccabeus
Corrected: during the times of Judas Maccabee
Review: during the times of Judas <mark><s>Maccabeus</s> Maccabee</mark>
Decision: Although Maccabeus is a more accurate transliteration of the Greek, Maccabee is common in English works and is used in all other occurrences in The Urantia Book.

Original: set upon their own selfish gain’.”
Corrected: set upon their own selfish gain.’”
Review: set upon their own selfish gain<mark>.’” <s>’.”</s></mark>
Decision: Quotation marks—single or double—should always enclose a comma or period.

Original: Lord open to us
Corrected: Lord, open to us
Review: Lord<mark>,</mark> open to us
Decision: In the original format, Lord was the last word in the line, making a dropped comma likely.

Original: I must needs to go prove it
Corrected: I must needs go to prove it
Review: I must needs <mark><s>to go</s> go to</mark> prove it
Decision: The original to go is a transposition resulting in a grammatically incorrect formulation.

Original: on the second, or even the third day,
Corrected: on the second or even the third day,
Review: on the second<mark><s>,</s></mark> or even the third day,
Decision: The form with only a comma following day is the most readable punctuation.

Original: he had become enamoured
Corrected: he had become enamored
Review: he had become <mark><s>enamoured</s> enamored</mark>
Decision: This word is also found at 121:5.6; there, the American spelling is used. The American form was adopted.

Original: until the day of the crucifixion
Corrected: until the days of the crucifixion
Review: until the day<mark>s</mark> of the crucifixion
Decision: The correction from day to days here is required because the former is inconsistent with the ensuing narrative.

Original: a certain beggar named Lazarus, who laid at
Corrected: a certain beggar named Lazarus, who was laid at
Review: a certain beggar named Lazarus, who <mark>was</mark> laid at
Decision: The authors of Part IV generally follow the text of the American Standard Version of 1901.

Original: so-called Messianic prophesies
Corrected: so-called Messianic prophecies
Review: so-called Messianic <mark><s>prophesies</s> prophecies</mark>
Decision: Prophesy is the spelling used for the verb, whereas prophecy is the correct spelling for the noun

Original: If any one asks you
Corrected: If anyone asks you
Review: If <mark><s>any one</s> anyone</mark> asks you
Decision: Anyone is correct if anybody could be substituted.

Original: his associates whom he feared might be led away
Corrected: his associates who he feared might be led away
Review: his associates <mark><s>whom</s> who</mark> he feared might be led away
Decision: The pronoun is the subject of the verb phrase might be led away, not the object of feared; therefore who is the correct form.

Original: some of the twelve whom he knew were armed
Corrected: some of the twelve who he knew were armed
Review: some of the twelve <mark><s>whom</s> who</mark> he knew were armed
Decision: The pronoun is the subject of the verb were armed, not the object of knew nor of were armed; therefore who is the correct form.

Original: the size of a ten cent piece
Corrected: the size of a ten-cent piece
Review: the size of a ten<mark>-</mark>cent piece
Decision: The hyphenated word ten-cent is the standard form and is specified by Chicago Manual of Style.

Original: except he who received
Corrected: except him who received
Review: except <mark><s>he</s> him</mark> who received
Decision: The pronoun is the object of the preposition except; therefore him is correct.

Original: willing to forego the great advantage
Corrected: willing to forgo the great advantage
Review: willing to <mark><s>forego</s> forgo</mark> the great advantage
Decision: The corrected spelling of forgo is etymologically preferable.

Original: shortly after 10 o’clock
Corrected: shortly after ten o’clock
Review: shortly after <mark><s>10</s> ten</mark> o’clock
Decision: The spelled-out form for time is clearly supported in Chicago Manual of Style.

Original: still others whom you think love the truth
Corrected: still others who you think love the truth
Review: still others <mark><s>whom</s> who</mark> you think love the truth
Decision: The pronoun is the subject of love, not the object of think; therefore who is the correct form.

Original: he said to the twelve
Corrected: he said to the eleven
Review: he said to the <mark><s>twelve</s> eleven</mark>
Decision: There were only eleven apostles with Jesus at this point in the narrative.

Original: you shall all some time sup with me
Corrected: you shall all sometime sup with me
Review: you shall all <mark><s>some time</s> sometime</mark> sup with me
Decision: The closed form is correct as the reference is to an indefinite point in time.

Original: even when faint-hearted believers turn
Corrected: even when fainthearted believers turn
Review: even when <mark><s>faint-hearted</s> fainthearted</mark> believers turn
Decision: This adverbial variant is particularly strange in hyphenated form, so the closed form was decided upon.

Original: to which you shall some time ascend
Corrected: to which you shall sometime ascend
Review: to which you shall <mark><s>some time</s> sometime</mark> ascend
Decision: The closed form is correct as the reference is to an indefinite point in time.

Original: informal charges of law-breaking
Corrected: informal charges of lawbreaking
Review: informal charges of <mark><s>law-breaking</s> lawbreaking</mark>
Decision: Of the five occurrences of lawbreaker and lawbreaking in the text, three are closed and two are hyphenated. There is no differential in meaning, so text standardization in the closed form was decided upon.

Original: with this law-breaker
Corrected: with this lawbreaker
Review: with this <mark><s>law-breaker</s> lawbreaker</mark>
Decision: Of the five occurrences of lawbreaker and lawbreaking in the text, three are closed and two are hyphenated. There is no differential in meaning, so text standardization in the closed form was decided upon.

Original: Sidon, Schechem, Hebron
Corrected: Sidon, Shechem, Hebron
Review: Sidon, <mark><s>Schecham</s> Shechem</mark>, Hebron
Decision: Shechem is the standard transliteration of the name.

Original: between man and his Maker on this world
Corrected: between man and his Maker, on this world
Review: between man and his Maker<mark>,</mark> on this world
Decision: The addition of the comma after Maker properly sets off the parenthetical phrase that follows.

Original: sandstorms from the Arabian desert
Corrected: sandstorms from the Arabian Desert
Review: sandstorms from the Arabian <mark><s>desert</s> Desert</mark>
Decision: The formatting of geographic names is covered by Chicago Manual of Style; the correct form is Arabian Desert.

Original: the evildoing of his ancestors
Corrected: the evil-doing of his ancestors
Review: the <mark><s>evildoing</s> evil-doing</mark> of his ancestors
Decision: There has been a clear preference for the hyphenated form since the seventeenth century.

Original: the tendency toward evildoing
Corrected: the tendency toward evil-doing
Review: the tendency toward <mark><s>evildoing</s> evil-doing</mark>
Decision: There has been a clear preference for the hyphenated form since the seventeenth century.

Original: suggested that any one claiming to have seen him
Corrected: suggested that anyone claiming to have seen him
Review: suggested that <mark><s>any one</s> anyone</mark> claiming to have seen him
Decision: Anyone is correct if anybody could be substituted.

Original: the far-away ascetics teach reverence
Corrected: the faraway ascetics teach reverence
Review: the <mark><s>far-away</s> faraway</mark> ascetics teach reverence
Decision: Except for this single instance, The Urantia Book uses the closed form.

Original: all their new concept of God
Corrected: all their new concepts of God
Review: all their new <mark><s>concept</s> concepts</mark> of God
Decision: The inclusion of all here requires the plural concepts.

Original: Poutaenus taught Clement and then went on
Corrected: Pantaenus taught Clement and then went on
Review: <mark><s>Poutaenus</s> Pantaenus</mark> taught Clement and then went on
Decision: Pantaenus is the correct spelling.

Original: the spirit of the Father is in his Son’s sons
Corrected: the spirit of the Father is in his Sons’ sons
Review: the spirit of the Father is in his <mark><s>Son’s</s> Sons’</mark> sons
Decision: Sons’ is correct in light of the prior sentence which provides the context: this life of the Father is in his Sons.
